--- title: Tibialis Anterior Muscle --- ![Muscles of the lower leg @OpenStaxAnatomyPhysiology2022](/The Archive/Images/OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology 2e/fig11.32 Muscles of the Lower Leg.jpeg){#fig-openstax-fig11.32} ![Intrinsic foot muscles @OpenStaxAnatomyPhysiology2022](/The Archive/Images/OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology 2e/fig11.34 Intrinsic Muscles of the Foot.jpeg){#fig-openstax-fig11.34} ![The Mucous sheaths of the tendons around the ankle (lateral view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Myology/image441 The mucous sheaths of the tendons around the ankle. Lateral aspect.gif) ![The Mucous sheaths of the tendons around the ankle (medial view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Myology/image442 The mucous sheaths of the tendons around the ankle. Medial aspect.gif) ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Tibialis Anterior Tibia (Upper 2/3 of lateral surface)
IO membrane
Superficial crural fascia		 Medial cuneiform (Medial & plantar surface)
1st Metatarsal (medial base)		 Deep Fibular n.
L4 - L5		 TCJ: DF
STJ: Inversion
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} - Tibia (upper 2/3 of the lateral surface) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Interosseous membrane @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Superficial crural fascia (highest part) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} - Medial cuneiform specifically the medial and plantar surfaces @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - 1st metatarsal (medial base) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 Functionally, the anterior tibialis inserts on the convex aspect of the medial arch @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Nerve [Deep Fibular N.]({{< var ref-deep-fibular-nerve.path >}}) ([L4]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l4 >}}), [L5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l5 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - **Talocrural joint**: Dorsiflexion - **Subtalar joint**: inversion (supination) The tibialis anterior works more as a supinator rather than an adductor @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Observation "The tendon of the tibialis anterior is visible at the level of the medial cuneiform and the base of the first metatarsal bone, especially if the foot is positioned in dorsiflexion and supination" @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 # Examination :::{layout-ncol="3"} ### MMT - DF/inv - "The tibialis anterior muscle produces the motion of dorsiflexion and inversion. The knee must remain flexed during the test to allow complete dorsiflexion. The patientâ€™s foot is positioned in dorsiflexion and inversion. The leg is stabilized, and resistance is applied to the medial posterior aspect of the forefoot into plantar flexion and eversion" @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 ### ROM - PF + EV ### Palpation ::: # Shin splints Tibialis anterior dysfunction can lead to [shin splints]({{< var ref-shin-splints.path >}}), more specifically [*anterior shin splints*]({{< var ref-anterior-shin-splints.path >}}).
